column2: Chapter VI.
column3: Chapter six.

column2: For Awhile A Very Obscure One
column3: For Awhile A Very Obscure One

column2: He would again be as solitary as ever, and though he had great hopes, and great--too great--expectations from life, he could not have given any definite account of his hopes, his expectations, or even his desires.
column3: He would again be as solitary as ever, and though he had great hopes, and great-too great-expectations from life, he could not have given any definite account of his hopes, his expectations, or even his desires.

column2: No, it's not that either.
column3: No, it's not that either.

column2: Is it the parting with Alyosha and the conversation I had with him?
column3: Is it the parting with Alyosha and the conversation I had with him?

column2: No doubt that came in, that vexation, it must have done indeed; but yet that was not it, that was not it either.
column3: No doubt that came in, that vexation, it must have done indeed; but yet that was not it, that was not it either.

column2: I feel sick with depression and yet I can't tell what I want.	I feel sick with depression and yet I can't tell what I want.
Better not think, perhaps."
column3: Better not think, perhaps."

column2: What made his depression so vexatious and irritating was that it had a kind of casual, external character--he felt that.
column3: What made his depression so vexatious and irritating was that it had a kind of casual, external character-he felt that.

column2: It all dawned upon him suddenly and became clear.
column3: It all dawned upon him suddenly and became clear.

column2: Afterwards, as he talked, Smerdyakov had been forgotten for the time; but still he had been in his mind, and as soon as Ivan parted with Alyosha and was walking home, the forgotten sensation began to obtrude itself again.
column3: Afterwards, as he talked, Smerdyakov had been forgotten for the time; but still he had been in his mind, and as soon as Ivan parted with Alyosha and was walking home, the forgotten sensation began to obtrude itself again.

column2: Is it possible that a miserable, contemptible creature like that can worry me so much? he wondered, with insufferable irritation.
column3: Is it possible that a miserable, contemptible creature like that can worry me so much? he wondered, with insufferable irritation.

column2: He had even begun to notice in himself a growing feeling that was almost of hatred for the creature. Perhaps this hatred was accentuated by the fact that when Ivan first came to the neighborhood he had felt quite differently.
column3: He had even begun to notice in himself a growing feeling that was almost of hatred for the creature. Perhaps this hatred was accentuated by the fact that when Ivan first came to the neighborhood he had felt quite differently.

column2: Then he had taken a marked interest in Smerdyakov, and had even thought him very original.
column3: Then he had taken a marked interest in Smerdyakov, and had even thought him very original.

column2: It had first given rise to his aversion.
column3: It had first given rise to his aversion.

column2: Grushenka had come on the scene, and there had been the scandals with his brother Dmitri--they discussed that, too.
column3: Grushenka had come on the scene, and there had been the scandals with his brother Dmitri-they discussed that, too.

column2: But though Smerdyakov always talked of that with great excitement, it was impossible to discover what he desired to come of it.
column3: But though Smerdyakov always talked of that with great excitement, it was impossible to discover what he desired to come of it.

column2: But what finally irritated Ivan most and confirmed his dislike for him was the peculiar, revolting familiarity which Smerdyakov began to show more and more markedly.
column3: But what finally irritated Ivan most and confirmed his dislike for him was the peculiar, revolting familiarity which Smerdyakov began to show more and more markedly.

column2: He always spoke in a tone that suggested that those two had some kind of compact, some secret between them, that had at some time been expressed on both sides, only known to them and beyond the comprehension of those around them.
column3: He always spoke in a tone that suggested that those two had some kind of compact, some secret between them, that had at some time been expressed on both sides, only known to them and beyond the comprehension of those around them.

column2: With a feeling of disgust and irritation he tried to pass in at the gate without speaking or looking at Smerdyakov.
column3: With a feeling of disgust and irritation he tried to pass in at the gate without speaking or looking at Smerdyakov.

column2: With anger and repulsion he looked at Smerdyakov's emasculate, sickly face, with the little curls combed forward on his forehead.
column3: With anger and repulsion he looked at Smerdyakov's emasculate, sickly face, with the little curls combed forward on his forehead.

column2: His left eye winked and he grinned as if to say, "Where are you going?
column3: His left eye winked and he grinned as if to say, "Where are you going?

column2: You won't pass by; you see that we two clever people have something to say to each other."
column3: You won't pass by; you see that we two clever people have something to say to each other."

column2: Get away, miserable idiot.	Get away, miserable idiot.
What have I to do with you?" was on the tip of his tongue, but to his profound astonishment he heard himself say, "Is my father still asleep, or has he waked?"
column3: What have I to do with you?" was on the tip of his tongue, but to his profound astonishment he heard himself say, "Is my father still asleep, or has he waked?"

column2: He asked the question softly and meekly, to his own surprise, and at once, again to his own surprise, sat down on the bench.
column3: He asked the question softly and meekly, to his own surprise, and at once, again to his own surprise, sat down on the bench.

column2: For an instant he felt almost frightened; he remembered it afterwards.
column3: For an instant he felt almost frightened; he remembered it afterwards.

column2: Smerdyakov stood facing him, his hands behind his back, looking at him with assurance and almost severity.
column3: Smerdyakov stood facing him, his hands behind his back, looking at him with assurance and almost severity.

column2: His honor is still asleep, he articulated deliberately ("You were the first to speak, not I," he seemed to say).
column3: His honor is still asleep, he articulated deliberately ("You were the first to speak, not I," he seemed to say).

column2: I am surprised at you, sir, he added, after a pause, dropping his eyes affectedly, setting his right foot forward, and playing with the tip of his polished boot.
column3: I am surprised at you, sir, he added, after a pause, dropping his eyes affectedly, setting his right foot forward, and playing with the tip of his polished boot.

column2: Why I smile you must understand of yourself, if you are a clever man, his screwed-up left eye seemed to say.
column3: Why I smile you must understand of yourself, if you are a clever man, his screwed up left eye seemed to say.

column2: Why should I go to Tchermashnya? Ivan asked in surprise.
column3: Why should I go to Tchermashnya? Ivan asked in surprise.

column2: Smerdyakov was silent again.
column3: Smerdyakov was silent again.

column2: I put you off with a secondary reason, he seemed to suggest, "simply to say something."
column3: I put you off with a secondary reason, he seemed to suggest, "simply to say something."

column2: Damn you!	Damn you!
Smerdyakov drew his right foot up to his left, pulled himself up, but still looked at him with the same serenity and the same little smile.
column3: Smerdyakov drew his right foot up to his left, pulled himself up, but still looked at him with the same serenity and the same little smile.

column2: Substantially nothing--but just by way of conversation.
column3: Substantially nothing-but just by way of conversation.

column2: They did not speak for nearly a minute.
column3: They did not speak for nearly a minute.

column2: At last he moved to get up.
column3: At last he moved to get up.

column2: Smerdyakov seemed to seize the moment.
column3: Smerdyakov seemed to seize the moment.

column2: I don't know how to help myself," he said resolutely and distinctly, and at his last word he sighed.
column3: I don't know how to help myself," he said resolutely and distinctly, and at his last word he sighed.

column2: I am speaking of your parent and your brother Dmitri Fyodorovitch.	I am speaking of your parent and your brother Dmitri Fyodorovitch.
Here Fyodor Pavlovitch will get up directly and begin worrying me every minute, 'Has she come?
column3: Here Fyodor Pavlovitch will get up directly and begin worrying me every minute, 'Has she come?

column2: Why hasn't she come?' and so on up till midnight and even after midnight.
column3: Why hasn't she come?' and so on up till midnight and even after midnight.

column2: When will she come?'--as though I were to blame for it.
column3: When will she come?'--as though I were to blame for it.

column2: On the other side it's no better. As soon as it gets dark, or even before, your brother will appear with his gun in his hands: 'Look out, you rogue, you soup-maker.
column3: On the other side it's no better. As soon as it gets dark, or even before, your brother will appear with his gun in his hands: 'Look out, you rogue, you soup maker.

column2: If you miss her and don't let me know she's been--I'll kill you before any one.' When the night's over, in the morning, he, too, like Fyodor Pavlovitch, begins worrying me to death.
column3: If you miss her and don't let me know she's been-I'll kill you before any one.' When the night's over, in the morning, he, too, like Fyodor Pavlovitch, begins worrying me to death.

column2: 'Why hasn't she come?
column3: 'Why hasn't she come?

column2: Will she come soon?' And he, too, thinks me to blame because his lady hasn't come.
column3: Will she come soon?' And he, too, thinks me to blame because his lady hasn't come.

column2: And why have you meddled?	And why have you meddled?
Why did you begin to spy for Dmitri Fyodorovitch?" said Ivan irritably.
column3: Why did you begin to spy for Dmitri Fyodorovitch?" said Ivan irritably.

column2: How could I help meddling?	How could I help meddling?
Though, indeed, I haven't meddled at all, if you want to know the truth of the matter.
column3: Though, indeed, I haven't meddled at all, if you want to know the truth of the matter.

column2: I kept quiet from the very beginning, not daring to answer; but he pitched on me to be his servant. He has had only one thing to say since: 'I'll kill you, you scoundrel, if you miss her,' I feel certain, sir, that I shall have a long fit to-morrow."
column3: I kept quiet from the very beginning, not daring to answer; but he pitched on me to be his servant. He has had only one thing to say since: 'I'll kill you, you scoundrel, if you miss her,' I feel certain, sir, that I shall have a long fit to morrow."

column2: I fell from the garret that time.
column3: I fell from the garret that time.

column2: The struggling ceased and then began again, and for three days I couldn't come back to my senses.
column3: The struggling ceased and then began again, and for three days I couldn't come back to my senses.

column2: I might have died."
column3: I might have died."

column2: What makes you say you will have one to-morrow?" Ivan inquired, with a peculiar, irritable curiosity.
column3: What makes you say you will have one to morrow?" Ivan inquired, with a peculiar, irritable curiosity.

column2: That's just so.	That's just so.
You can't tell beforehand."
column3: You can't tell beforehand."

column2: I climb up to the garret every day.	I climb up to the garret every day.
I might fall from the garret again to-morrow.
column3: I might fall from the garret again to morrow.

column2: And, if not, I might fall down the cellar steps.
column3: And, if not, I might fall down the cellar steps.

column2: I have to go into the cellar every day, too."
column3: I have to go into the cellar every day, too."

column2: Ivan took a long look at him.
column3: Ivan took a long look at him.

column2: You are talking nonsense, I see, and I don't quite understand you, he said softly, but with a sort of menace.
column3: You are talking nonsense, I see, and I don't quite understand you, he said softly, but with a sort of menace.

column2: Do you mean to pretend to be ill to-morrow for three days, eh?
column3: Do you mean to pretend to be ill to morrow for three days, eh?

column2: Smerdyakov, who was looking at the ground again, and playing with the toe of his right foot, set the foot down, moved the left one forward, and, grinning, articulated:
column3: Smerdyakov, who was looking at the ground again, and playing with the toe of his right foot, set the foot down, moved the left one forward, and, grinning, articulated:

column2: If I were able to play such a trick, that is, pretend to have a fit--and it would not be difficult for a man accustomed to them--I should have a perfect right to use such a means to save myself from death.	If I were able to play such a trick, that is, pretend to have a fit-and it would not be difficult for a man accustomed to them-I should have a perfect right to use such a means to save myself from death.
He'd be ashamed to."
column3: He'd be ashamed to."

column2: All my brother Dmitri's threats are only hasty words and mean nothing.
column3: All my brother Dmitri's threats are only hasty words and mean nothing.

column2: He'd kill me first of all, like a fly.	He'd kill me first of all, like a fly.
But even more than that, I am afraid I shall be taken for an accomplice of his when he does something crazy to his father."
column3: But even more than that, I am afraid I shall be taken for an accomplice of his when he does something crazy to his father."

column2: Why should you be taken for an accomplice?
column3: Why should you be taken for an accomplice?

column2: What signals?	What signals?
Whom did you tell?
column3: Whom did you tell?

column2: Confound you, speak more plainly."
column3: Confound you, speak more plainly."

column2: I'm bound to admit the fact, Smerdyakov drawled with pedantic composure, "that I have a secret with Fyodor Pavlovitch in this business.
column3: I'm bound to admit the fact, Smerdyakov drawled with pedantic composure, "that I have a secret with Fyodor Pavlovitch in this business.

column2: As you know yourself (if only you do know it) he has for several days past locked himself in as soon as night or even evening comes on.
column3: As you know yourself (if only you do know it) he has for several days past locked himself in as soon as night or even evening comes on.

column2: Of late you've been going upstairs to your room early every evening, and yesterday you did not come down at all, and so perhaps you don't know how carefully he has begun to lock himself in at night, and even if Grigory Vassilyevitch comes to the door he won't open to him till he hears his voice.
column3: Of late you've been going upstairs to your room early every evening, and yesterday you did not come down at all, and so perhaps you don't know how carefully he has begun to lock himself in at night, and even if Grigory Vassilyevitch comes to the door he won't open to him till he hears his voice.

column2: That's the arrangement he made himself ever since this to-do with Agrafena Alexandrovna began.
column3: That's the arrangement he made himself ever since this to do with Agrafena Alexandrovna began.

column2: You look out for her,' says he, 'till midnight and later; and if she does come, you run up and knock at my door or at the window from the garden.
column3: You look out for her,' says he, 'till midnight and later; and if she does come, you run up and knock at my door or at the window from the garden.

column2: At first, two knocks, and then, after an interval, another much louder.
column3: At first, two knocks, and then, after an interval, another much louder.

column2: Then he will understand that something has happened suddenly and that I must see him, and he will open to me so that I can go and speak to him.
column3: Then he will understand that something has happened suddenly and that I must see him, and he will open to me so that I can go and speak to him.

column2: That's all in case Agrafena Alexandrovna can't come herself, but sends a message.
column3: That's all in case Agrafena Alexandrovna can't come herself, but sends a message.

column2: Besides, Dmitri Fyodorovitch might come, too, so I must let him know he is near.
column3: Besides, Dmitri Fyodorovitch might come, too, so I must let him know he is near.

column2: His honor is awfully afraid of Dmitri Fyodorovitch, so that even if Agrafena Alexandrovna had come and were locked in with him, and Dmitri Fyodorovitch were to turn up anywhere near at the time, I should be bound to let him know at once, knocking three times.
column3: His honor is awfully afraid of Dmitri Fyodorovitch, so that even if Agrafena Alexandrovna had come and were locked in with him, and Dmitri Fyodorovitch were to turn up anywhere near at the time, I should be bound to let him know at once, knocking three times.

column2: So that the first signal of five knocks means Agrafena Alexandrovna has come, while the second signal of three knocks means 'something important to tell you.' His honor has shown me them several times and explained them.
column3: So that the first signal of five knocks means Agrafena Alexandrovna has come, while the second signal of three knocks means 'something important to tell you.' His honor has shown me them several times and explained them.

column2: Well, those signals are known to Dmitri Fyodorovitch too, now."
column3: Well, those signals are known to Dmitri Fyodorovitch too, now."

column2: How are they known?	How are they known?
Did you tell him?
column3: Did you tell him?

column2: How dared you tell him?"
column3: How dared you tell him?"

column2: How could I dare to keep it back from him?
column3: How could I dare to keep it back from him?

column2: I'll break both your legs for you.' So I told him those secret signals that he might see my slavish devotion, and might be satisfied that I was not deceiving him, but was telling him all I could."
column3: I'll break both your legs for you.' So I told him those secret signals that he might see my slavish devotion, and might be satisfied that I was not deceiving him, but was telling him all I could."

column2: Hang it!	Hang it!
How can you be so sure you are going to have a fit, confound you?
column3: How can you be so sure you are going to have a fit, confound you?

column2: Are you laughing at me?"
column3: Are you laughing at me?"

column2: I am in no laughing humor with this fear on me.
column3: I am in no laughing humor with this fear on me.

column2: I feel I am going to have a fit.
column3: I feel I am going to have a fit.

column2: I have a presentiment.
column3: I have a presentiment.

column2: Fright alone will bring it on."
column3: Fright alone will bring it on."

column2: Confound it!	Confound it!
If you are laid up, Grigory will be on the watch.
column3: If you are laid up, Grigory will be on the watch.

column2: Let Grigory know beforehand; he will be sure not to let him in."
column3: Let Grigory know beforehand; he will be sure not to let him in."

column2: And as for Grigory Vassilyevitch hearing him and not admitting him, he has been ill ever since yesterday, and Marfa Ignatyevna intends to give him medicine to-morrow.
column3: And as for Grigory Vassilyevitch hearing him and not admitting him, he has been ill ever since yesterday, and Marfa Ignatyevna intends to give him medicine to morrow.

column2: It's a very strange remedy of hers.
column3: It's a very strange remedy of hers.

column2: Marfa Ignatyevna knows of a preparation and always keeps it.
column3: Marfa Ignatyevna knows of a preparation and always keeps it.

column2: And when Grigory Vassilyevitch wakes up he is perfectly well after it, but Marfa Ignatyevna always has a headache from it.
column3: And when Grigory Vassilyevitch wakes up he is perfectly well after it, but Marfa Ignatyevna always has a headache from it.

column2: So, if Marfa Ignatyevna carries out her intention to-morrow, they won't hear anything and hinder Dmitri Fyodorovitch. They'll be asleep."
column3: So, if Marfa Ignatyevna carries out her intention to morrow, they won't hear anything and hinder Dmitri Fyodorovitch. They'll be asleep."

column2: What a rigmarole!	What a rigmarole!
And it all seems to happen at once, as though it were planned.
column3: And it all seems to happen at once, as though it were planned.

column2: How could I?...	How could I?...
If he means to do anything, he'll do it; but if not, I shan't be thrusting him upon his father."
column3: If he means to do anything, he'll do it; but if not, I shan't be thrusting him upon his father."

column2: You say that yourself, and all the while I've been here, I've felt sure it was all the old man's fancy, and the creature won't come to him.	You say that yourself, and all the while I've been here, I've felt sure it was all the old man's fancy, and the creature won't come to him.
Why should Dmitri break in on him if she doesn't come? Speak, I want to know what you are thinking!"
column3: Why should Dmitri break in on him if she doesn't come? Speak, I want to know what you are thinking!"

column2: You know yourself why he'll come.	You know yourself why he'll come.

His honor will come simply because he is in a rage or suspicious on account of my illness perhaps, and he'll dash in, as he did yesterday through impatience to search the rooms, to see whether she hasn't escaped him on the sly.
column3: His honor will come simply because he is in a rage or suspicious on account of my illness perhaps, and he'll dash in, as he did yesterday through impatience to search the rooms, to see whether she hasn't escaped him on the sly.

column2: He is perfectly well aware, too, that Fyodor Pavlovitch has a big envelope with three thousand roubles in it, tied up with ribbon and sealed with three seals.
column3: He is perfectly well aware, too, that Fyodor Pavlovitch has a big envelope with three thousand roubles in it, tied up with ribbon and sealed with three seals.

column2: Dmitri won't come to steal money and kill my father to do it.	Dmitri won't come to steal money and kill my father to do it.
He might have killed him yesterday on account of Grushenka, like the frantic, savage fool he is, but he won't steal."
column3: He might have killed him yesterday on account of Grushenka, like the frantic, savage fool he is, but he won't steal."

column2: You don't know in what need he is," Smerdyakov explained, with perfect composure and remarkable distinctness.
column3: You don't know in what need he is," Smerdyakov explained, with perfect composure and remarkable distinctness.

column2: He looks on that three thousand as his own, too.	He looks on that three thousand as his own, too.
He said so to me himself.
column3: He said so to me himself.

column2: 'My father still owes me just three thousand,' he said.
column3: 'My father still owes me just three thousand,' he said.

column2: It's as good as certain, so to say, that Agrafena Alexandrovna will force him, if only she cares to, to marry her--the master himself, I mean, Fyodor Pavlovitch--if only she cares to, and of course she may care to.
column3: It's as good as certain, so to say, that Agrafena Alexandrovna will force him, if only she cares to, to marry her-the master himself, I mean, Fyodor Pavlovitch-if only she cares to, and of course she may care to.

column2: All I've said is that she won't come, but maybe she's looking for more than that--I mean to be mistress here.
column3: All I've said is that she won't come, but maybe she's looking for more than that-I mean to be mistress here.

column2: And she's got plenty of sense.
column3: And she's got plenty of sense.

column2: But if your father were to die now, there'd be some forty thousand for sure, even for Dmitri Fyodorovitch whom he hates so, for he's made no will....
column3: But if your father were to die now, there'd be some forty thousand for sure, even for Dmitri Fyodorovitch whom he hates so, for he's made no will....

column2: Dmitri Fyodorovitch knows all that very well."
column3: Dmitri Fyodorovitch knows all that very well."

column2: A sort of shudder passed over Ivan's face.
column3: A sort of shudder passed over Ivan's face.

column2: He suddenly flushed.
column3: He suddenly flushed.

column2: What did you mean by that?
column3: What did you mean by that?

column2: Precisely so, said Smerdyakov, softly and reasonably, watching Ivan intently, however.
column3: Precisely so, said Smerdyakov, softly and reasonably, watching Ivan intently, however.

column2: What do you mean by 'precisely so'? Ivan questioned him, with a menacing light in his eyes, restraining himself with difficulty.
column3: What do you mean by 'precisely so'? Ivan questioned him, with a menacing light in his eyes, restraining himself with difficulty.

column2: I spoke because I felt sorry for you.	I spoke because I felt sorry for you.
If I were in your place I should simply throw it all up ... rather than stay on in such a position," answered Smerdyakov, with the most candid air looking at Ivan's flashing eyes.
column3: If I were in your place I should simply throw it all up ... rather than stay on in such a position," answered Smerdyakov, with the most candid air looking at Ivan's flashing eyes.

column2: They were both silent.
column3: They were both silent.

column2: He was about to pass straight through the gate, but he stopped short and turned to Smerdyakov.
column3: He was about to pass straight through the gate, but he stopped short and turned to Smerdyakov.

column2: Something strange followed.
column3: Something strange followed.

column2: I am going away to Moscow to-morrow, if you care to know--early to-morrow morning.	I am going away to Moscow to morrow, if you care to know-early to morrow morning.
That's all!" he suddenly said aloud angrily, and wondered himself afterwards what need there was to say this then to Smerdyakov.
column3: That's all!" he suddenly said aloud angrily, and wondered himself afterwards what need there was to say this then to Smerdyakov.

column2: That's the best thing you can do, he responded, as though he had expected to hear it; "except that you can always be telegraphed for from Moscow, if anything should happen here."
column3: That's the best thing you can do, he responded, as though he had expected to hear it; "except that you can always be telegraphed for from Moscow, if anything should happen here."

column2: Ivan stopped again, and again turned quickly to Smerdyakov.
column3: Ivan stopped again, and again turned quickly to Smerdyakov.

column2: But a change had passed over him, too.
column3: But a change had passed over him, too.

column2: All his familiarity and carelessness had completely disappeared.
column3: All his familiarity and carelessness had completely disappeared.

column2: His face expressed attention and expectation, intent but timid and cringing.
column3: His face expressed attention and expectation, intent but timid and cringing.

column2: From Tchermashnya, too ... you could be sent for, Smerdyakov muttered, almost in a whisper, looking disconcerted, but gazing intently into Ivan's eyes.
column3: From Tchermashnya, too ... you could be sent for, Smerdyakov muttered, almost in a whisper, looking disconcerted, but gazing intently into Ivan's eyes.

column2: Only Moscow is farther and Tchermashnya is nearer.	Only Moscow is farther and Tchermashnya is nearer.
Is it to save my spending money on the fare, or to save my going so far out of my way, that you insist on Tchermashnya?"
column3: Is it to save my spending money on the fare, or to save my going so far out of my way, that you insist on Tchermashnya?"
